stem: A 15-year-old client is 6 hours post-reduction of a tibial fracture with a plaster cast. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Severe pain refractory to opioids.
Background: Tibial fracture repair. Cast applied 6 hours ago.
Assessment: Client is screaming and reporting 10/10 pain despite IV morphine.
Recommendation: Immediate surgical consult for compartment check.

tabs.title: Neurovascular Flowsheet
tabs.content:

Pain Level10/10 (Persistent)Pain out of proportion
Passive MotionPain with passive extension of toesClassic early sign

actionOptions.text: Loosen or cut the restrictive dressing or cast
Maintain the affected limb at the level of the heart
Elevate the limb above the level of the heart
Apply ice packs and maintain high-pressure compression

rationale.correct: This client has Acute Compartment Syndrome (c2), as evidenced by pain out of proportion to the injury (10/10) and pain with passive toe extensionâ€”the first sign. Priority actions involve removing external pressure by loosening the cast (a1) and keeping the leg at HEART LEVEL (a2). Elevating it (a3) would worsen ischemia by reducing arterial flow. Parameters focus on the 6 Ps (p1) and monitoring compartment pressures (p2).
clinicalPearls: The 6 Ps: Pain, Paresthesia, Pallor, Paralysis, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia.
PARALYSIS and PULSELESSNESS are LATE signs. If you wait for them, the limb is likely dead.
Fasciotomy is the definitive surgical treatment.

questionTrap.trap: Elevating the leg for compartment syndrome.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Elevation is for SWELLING/EDEMA (Veins). Level-with-heart is for ISCHEMIA (Arteries). Compartment syndrome is an arterial/perfusion issue; do not elevate.

mnemonic.title: The 6 Ps
mnemonic.expansion: Pain. Pressure. Paresthesia. Pallor. Paralysis. Pulselessness.
